When I v/as visited by the R.A.F. representatives I had had no opportunity of examining the figures relating to R.A.F. vehicles and I informed them that whatever I said was subject to what might appear after I had discussed the matter with the State Engineer who deals with this matter. 2. The arrangement which is now in force was agreed upon by the R.A.F. as it apparently suited them and as far as the Bahrain Government is concerned it appears to be equitable. 3. The Bahrain Government is not prepared to accept a payment of im.1,000/- per month on account of all R.A.F. vehicles using the Manama-Muharraq causeway and the Shaikh Hamad Bridge. In this connection I assume that 'Sitra” in the R.A.F. letter enclosed in yours should read 'Manama”. 4. The Bahrain Government is willing to provide books of tickets at the normal rate, for all types of vehicles, which can be used by drivers of R.A.F. vehicles. This would obviate tne need for any cash transactions at the gate and would ensure that the R.A.F. did not pay for more crossings than they actually made. Adviser to the Government of Bahrain, Bahrain, Persian Gulf. To His Britannic Majesty T s Political Agent, Bahrain. Sir2 5. As an alternative the Bahrain Government is willing to accept from the R.A.F. an account at the end of each month showing the vehicles of different types which have used the bridge with the number of actual journeys made by each vehicle. I understand that all drivers keep log books so it would be possible to keep a record of crossings. The charge would then be assessed according to the standard basic rates. This method would not necessitate the use of tickets thoughit it might be necessary to increase the bridge personnel should a check be desirable. 6. If the R.A.F. could exercise a more efficient system of control to ensure that each vehicle makes the maximum possible number of trips accross the bridge the amount of bridge tolls could be considerably reduced. At present, for example, if 10 journeys are made separately by each of 10 vehicles (100 journeys) the charge on the monthly season ticket rate would be 10 x 30 300/-, if however 100 journeys were made by 2 vehicles (50 journeys each) the charge would be 2 x 301= 60/-. 7. Bridge tolls are collected in order to provide a fund for maintaining the bridge and also to cover depre ciation on the bridge. The large numbers of heavy military vehicles which are now crossing the bridge have a direct bearing upon the rate of fatigue caused by stress set up by the weight of traffic supported by the bridge structure. This is apart from the wear and tear on the roads, especially within the Muharraq Municipality area, which is caused by military heavy traffic. Vehicles which are not military pay vehicle taxes and this contributes towards the cost of the upkeep of roads, a proportion of this revenue is paid to the two Municipalities for their share in road work but in 2 /— ^ j 2,fact at the present time military vehicles are using the town roads and the causeway more than civilian traffic. physicalDescription.extent: The file is arranged in chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 53; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located at the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-44; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence regarding use of the Manama to Muharraq causeway (Shaikh Hamad Bridge) in Bahrain. The correspondence is between the Adviser to the Government of Bahrain (Charles Dalrymple Belgrave), Political Agency in Bahrain, Political Residency in the Persian Gulf, Office of the Air Liaison Officer, and the State Engineer.Several matters are discussed in the file, including:the amount to be paid and the form of payment for regular use of the bridge by Royal Air Force vehicles and those of the United States of America Transport Command;complaints from small craft users about the toll charged to go under the bridge;the registration of Agency and Residency vehicles that may use the bridge free of charge.Folios 49-52 are internal office notes.
